bestBHT.bht: When Paul was bitten by a viper in Malta, onlookers viewed it as an extraordinary coincidence or as evidence of his divine nature. However, Luke, who understood the locals, could confirm the true nature of the incident. By shaking off the snake, Paul demonstrated unwavering trust in God's promises and remained calm even amidst the danger. This miraculous event not only spared Paul from harm but also silenced doubts about his calling and authority, serving as a powerful testament to God's faithfulness and protection.

Henry Alford: According to these rationalists, a fortunate concurrence of accidents must have happened to the Apostles, totally unprecedented in history or probability.

None were so well qualified to judge of the virulence of the serpent,—none so capable of knowing that the hanging on Paul’s hand implied the communication of the venom:—yet they change him from a murderer into a god, on seeing what took place.
The fact that St. Luke understood what the natives said, is adduced by Dr. Wordsworth as another proof...that the Apostles and Evangelists commonly understood unknown tongues.

Albert Barnes: And he shook off ... - In this was remarkably fulfilled the promise of the Saviour Mark 16:18; “They shall take up serpents,” etc.
Marvin Vincent: Treacle, therefore, is originally a preparation of viper's flesh, and was used later of any antidote.

The saints' experiences help them to a sovereign treacle made of the scorpion's own flesh (which they through Christ have slain), and that hath a virtue above all other to expel the venom of Satan's temptations from the heart.
We kill the viper and make treacle of him.
John Calvin: The shaking off of the viper is a token of a quiet mind.
Faith doth not make us blockish, as brain-sick men do imagine, when they be out of danger.

Though Paul understand that the viper was a noisome beast, yet did he trust to the promise which was made to him, and did not so fear her plaguy biting, that it did trouble him; because he was even ready to die if need had been.
Philip Schaff: Acts 28:5. Felt no harm. We see here part of the fulfilment of the promise in Mark 16:12, words which were doubtless fulfilled in other instances likewise.
Archibald T. Robertson: Shook off (αποτιναξας). First aorist active participle of αποτινασσω, to shake off. Rare word (Euripides, Galen, LXX). In N.T. only here and Luke 9:5.
John Gill: And he shook off the beast into the fire... as not being afraid of it."
Having held it a while... though it was the ready way to provoke it to fasten on him again."
And felt no harm; it having not bit him, nor infected him with its poison.
John Wesley: No venomous kind of serpent now breeds in Malta, neither hurts if it be brought thither from another place."
Children are seen there handling and playing even with scorpions; I have seen one eating them."
If this be so, it seems to be fixed by the wisdom of God, as an eternal memorial of what he once wrought there.
